section.title: Derivative Units
section.p: We can think about the instantaneous velocity as being the instantaneous rate of change in position. In general, whenever you see the phrase rate of change you can assume that the rate of change at one instant is being discussed. When we want to discuss average rates of change over a time interval we always say average rate of change.

In general, if f is any function, then \fe{\fd{f}}{a} tells us the rate of change in f at a. Additionally, if f is an applied function with an input unit of i_{\text{unit}} and an output unit of f_{\text{unit}}, then the unit on \fe{\fd{f}}{a} is \frac{f_{\text{unit}}}{i_{\text{unit}}}. Please note that this unit loses all meaning if it is simplified in any way. Consequently, we do not simplify derivative units in any way, shape, or form.

For example, if \fe{v}{t} is the velocity of your car (measured in ) where t is the amount of time that has passed since you hit the road (measured in minutes), then the unit on \fe{\fd{v}}{t} is \frac{\text{mi}/\text{h}}{\text{min}}.

introduction.p: Determine the unit for the first derivative function for each of the following functions. Remember, we do not simplify derivative units in any way, shape, or form.

statement.p: \fe{V}{r} is the volume of a sphere (measured in ) with radius r (measured in ).
\fe{A}{x} is the area of a square (measured in ) with sides of length x (measured in ).
\fe{V}{t} is the volume of water in a bathtub (measured in ) where t is the amount of time that has elapsed since the bathtub began to drain (measured in minutes).
\fe{R}{t} is the rate at which a bathtub is draining (measured in ) where t is the amount of time that has elapsed since the bathtub began to drain (measured in minutes).
